reviewText:
It's unfortunate that this game didn't get as much traction as planned.

Although short and tedious at times, LoTR: War in The North is a great 3 person co-op game that takes place at the same time the fellowship is being formed. From the same team that brought you Baldurs Gate: Dark Alliance, comes a third person LoTR game. A very simple hack and slash with not much else in terms of variety. Yes you have an inventory, yes there is a good amount of items to obtain and equip, but it's a very run of the mill RPG.

The one cool thing about this game is that it's rated M, which doesn't sound like it's a really game changing feature, but it shows a lot that other LoTR games can't, and it gives a certain realism and gritty feeling while playing the game, which really brings you in to the Middle Earth Environment.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes LoTR, or Baldurs Gate. make sure your friends play with you too, because going through middle earth by yourself isn't a lot of fun.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A decent mutiplayer-focused adventure, best consumed with friends.
War in the North capably follows in the footsteps of the old LotR action games. While not as tightly constructed as its predecessors, the broadened RPG elements and online functionality safely glides the game into the recommendable category. Each character plays uniquely enough, with three skills trees each to vary things even more. The combat plays similar enough to the aforesaid games, albeit with some Arkham counter-attacks thrown in. Very fun. Very silly.

But be warned...
That said, if you're searching for an expansive single-player RPG, keep looking. This game was made for online coop, something blatantly evident during offline party management. Simply described, there are two inventories: the player's inventory and the AI's inventory. The player's inventory encompasses any currently controlled character (whichever they may be), whether offline or online. But the AI's exists utterly autonomously (as it would with another player).

So say you're playing the ranger when you pick up a nice axe you'd like to use when playing the dwarf. To trade it, you need to save and exit the current game and reenter as the dwarf character. Think of it as logging and relogging between two toons on an MMO, except all of your characters share the same loot bags. Conversely, and this is IMPORTANT, if you just trade the axe to the cpu version of the dwarf, the item will be cast into the nether: the cpu's inventory. You will not get it back. You cannot force the npc to wield it. When you log into the dwarf character, you will not find it.

This extends to leveling up as well. As much as you may enjoy playing a particular character, I highly advise you regularly redo previous missions with whatever characters you've been neglecting. They will not level up or progress their skill branches on their own. They will gain XP, to be fair, but they become increasingly outmatched as the game goes on. So if you rock the first six levels with the dwarf and decide to finally switch things up and finish the game as the elf, prepare to be overwhelmed.

reviewText: First off... PLAY THIS GAME WITH FRIENDS! It's no fun playing this game solo. reviewText:
This game is great. Do not look to the negative reviews from 3 years ago for advice. It has since been updated, and now plays fairly well with little or no problems. However, Carn Dum gave me a lot of trouble. The game dropped frames like it was having a seizure. I eventually got past that part, but not after the game crashed not once or twice, but three times.
Be aware that you may die in this game A LOT. But once you get the hang of it, its very, very fun.
Be prepared to kill Orcs, Uruk-Hai, Trolls, and evil men Legolas and Aragorn style (if playing as the man, Eradan). I recently tried playing as Farin as well. He's basically Gimli with a different voice and a crossbow. The crossbow is useful because you can get an upgrade that allows for an explosive bolt every once in a while. However, Farin is fairly slow as compared to Eradan and Andriel, and seems to die fairly easily as compared to them as well.
In conclusion, I give this game a 9.5/10 for awesome combat, a good story, and great enemies.

reviewText:
It has a great potential, but it is simply full of terrifying bugs, which will make your way through the game in some parts, a nightmare.

ATTENTION: there's that problem with AMD graphics drivers, if you want your game without crashing you need 12.6 or older drivers for AMD, otherwise your game is very prone to crashing, especially in chapter 2 and 8.
(Nvidia should be OK)

Honestly if you are going to play this game with your friends like I did, you will have a lot of saving bugs (saving disabled for the one who's not host), then for example that bug with your friends armor (sometimes you can't see them wearing it) or you won't be able to finish some of the sidequests because you missed that part too fast...

I would recommend this game only if you really like Lord of the Rings and you have some friends to play with.

reviewText: I remember when this game came out that it got a LOT of negative press and the sales were moderate at best. I really can not fathom why. Looking at the game (which was made for consoles and later ported to PC) I'd give it a 9/10. It offers really excellent storytelling and TONS of lore and LOTR backstory that you would miss out on in a pure action RPG. I also really enjoyed the cooperative experience the game provided, as I haven't had something like it since the days of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance. Playing the game alone is alright, but cooping it with 2 friends makes it outstanding.  My only complaint is that is a straight from console port, which means the textures and graphics quality don't keep up with what is normal" for pc games these days. That being said

reviewText: With some of the glitches i've experienced playing this game in co-op mode, i'd considered giving this game a thumbs down.  But even with the glitches I can't really walk away from this game.  For any fan of Middle Earth, this is just stunning.  The graphics are beautiful and incredible and the lore is pretty spot on.  You play as a small group that fights in the north to buy time for the fellowship of the ring.  You get to encounter six of the members of the fellowship, along with other notable characters.  And they really bring a sense of familiarity, the character models were designed to resemble the cast from the films.\n\nAll in all, I really, really love this game.  Glitches be damned.

reviewText:
A decent game, if you know what you're going to get

I really did enjoy this game. I love the Tolkein universe and I think the idea of the story running parallel to the story from the Lord of the Rings Trilogy worked well here. Do not expect an RPG experience, this is much more of a hack and slash, and there are many moments that break the 'immersion' of an RPG game (randomly buying items, mid level, from a floating pool of light, etc.).

Story/Presentation: 6/10

Agandaur, a high ranking commander of Sauron's forces is marching to destroy the north, and you must stop him. That is the meat of the story. Whilst this is nothing original, and there are no plot twists and things to keep you guessing, it serves its job well enough. The story is fleshed out with characters from the Original LOTR story (Gandalf, Aragorn etc.) and it works well to keep to the original lore (from what I know). There are side quests, but they are sparse and sometimes hard to give a crap about. I finished many of them without even realising (found an item from killing an orc, turns out a dwarf wanted it for a quest).
I say 6/10 because as stories go, it is hard to go wrong when Tolkein has done the bulk of the work! The thing that brings this score down to me is how bland the playable characters are. There are many characters in this game that have quite interesting personas, the playable characters are not among them.

Gameplay: 5.5/10

Nothing inventive here. I played the ranger all the way through, and although the abilities that you learn (from a talent tree similar to world of warcraft), I found that most of the time you'll be mashing the attack button from start to finish. There are some AI problems, if your allies (who were clearly designed to be played by friends) see a ranged unit, they will walk slowly towards them, shooting at them, whilst melee heroes hack them to pieces. Other than that the AI is actually quite fine. I will also note here that you can 'switch character', but you lose all items from your first character unless you switch back again, so I really don't see the point. It seems like a big design flaw to me, but I had no need to change my character anyway. 5.5/10 because it serves its purpose fine, and there's a lot of gore and fun to be had, but at the end of the day its too repetitive.

Visuals: 8/10

Whilst the graphics are nothing to rave about, they are really quite good. The linearity of the game means that the surrounding environments look quite beautiful, and there has been quite a lot of effort clearly put in to the design of the scenes. I am also going to mention the gore as well, it is nice to see a bit of blood and severred limbs that is startlingly absent in almost all Lord of the Rings games. The hack and slash gameplay IS quite repetitive, but lopping heads and arms off never really gets old.

Replayability 6/10

Whilst I doubt I will play through the game again, there is the option to do so with a higher difficulty, and naturally with another player character. I think this is a nice idea, but personally I would have rather put the difficulty higher on my first playthrough, than be forced to wait until I've completed the game once. That being said, it's a nice option, and I think many will enjoy playing through again with a second character.

Conclusion: 6/10

A fun game, nothing special, but worth a play through. I don't think this game is worth a full price purchase, but if you see it on offer definitely give it a go. I got this game from the humble bundle, and I thought I'd end up brushing over if but I'm glad that I didn't. Take that for what it's worth!

reviewText:
This is your generic fantasy rpg game. I would not even bother with it if not for the setting...Middle Earth ! And damn it adds a lot to the game. You can play as 1 of 3 characters (elf healer/mage , dwarf warrior / crossbow guy  and the ranger / tank dunadain.(2-handed sword dunadain warrior op:) ). Anyway I picked it up with 2 other friends and I really had fun...until I started getting blue screens. I dnk why I encountered this problem since my computer never behaved like this with any other game and i meet the specs with ease. It was not from the graphics settings of the game (tried so many options) and it felt really random (would happen at random times in the game , not even twice in the same place). Just wanted to lay that out before I continue. The action / Rpg elements are solid with different talent trees (and the leveling is at a good pace) , a lot of loot (that also changes how your character looks) and the coombat feels good and smooth , fluid. The graphics are decent , but an RPG is not about the graphics and since the gameplay is good i am willing to overlook that. The story is your pretty tipical fantasy story with a middle earth setting , but I admit I enjoy that (although it is predictable). The voice acting though , it's kinda on the low side. Also playing with friends increases the value of the game so much so keep that in mind.


In conclusion I would say that you should buy this game at full price if you are aware that you might encounter bugs and blue screens and are ok with it and if you have friends to play with.Otherwise wait for a sale if you want to buy it as playing alone will soon become boring and start to feel like a chore.

reviewText:
This game is amazing co op.

There's a great amount of loot to find. Wich I personally think is one of the best parts about the game.

Many orcs, trolls, spiders and so on to dismember and slay. Awesome battles. And fairly gory which is kind of cool really.

Your character can learn some pretty sweet combat moves. The combat isn't super deep though, but that didn't bother me.

Quite a lot of characters to talk to if you're interested in the lore aspect. If not you can just quickly click through the conversations.

I also find the graphics to be pretty nice looking at some points wich is a +

But beware! A big warning!! This game can be pretty ridiculously buggy and glitchy. I played the entire game in a LAN setup. One of my computers handled it without a problem. My second one had really bad stuttering and some crashes. Also at one point the character I used on that computer somehow lost all his equipment and gained the same equipment my friends character had instead. Not sure what went wrong there.

If you accept all the problems some computers might have with this game it is awesome and you should get it. And should propably play it cooperatively.

reviewText: I remember when this game came out that it got a LOT of negative press and the sales were moderate at best. I really can not fathom why. Looking at the game (which was made for consoles and later ported to PC) I'd give it a 9/10. It offers really excellent storytelling and TONS of lore and LOTR backstory that you would miss out on in a pure action RPG. I also really enjoyed the cooperative experience the game provided, as I haven't had something like it since the days of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance. Playing the game alone is alright, but cooping it with 2 friends makes it outstanding.  My only complaint is that is a straight from console port, which means the textures and graphics quality don't keep up with what is normal" for pc games these days. That being said
date: the animations are very smooth and pleasing to do and look at. The music is fantastic and rings true of LOTR
recommended: and the voice acting is actually pretty decent. (Much better than I was expecting

reviewText:
War in the North is a great co-op experience when it works.  With a limited number of co-op games on the market and fewer that are good, this game is worth a shot if you want to play with some friends online.  However, note that you will most likely run into some if not many bugs that plague this game.  Several times in the game my friends and I encountered save file corruption bugs, random crashes, and glitches that prevent progression.  Thankfully, since we were playing co-op many of the bugs could be bypassed by switching who was the host of the game and reloading the mission.

One big annoyance is the fact that the in game voice chat cannot be turned off or muted.  The audio quality is horrible (for one friend the audio was incomprehensible) and  sound effects are added to the audio to try and make it sound like you are in a cave when in your character in the game is in a cave.  There is one workaround to this for compatible sound card/drivers where you set your default microphone as a Stereo Mix" or similar functionality and then select your real microphone in your team chat software.

If you decide to play this game
date:
make sure you periodically back up your save files located at "%LocalAppData%\WB Games\War in the North".

Also before playing the last mission of "Carn Dun" make sure that you complete all the desired side quests and challenge missions because when you beat the game your save file game progress is reset (you still keep your levels and items) starting you back at the beginning of the game.  Also for the game host the game difficulty is automatically increased for the next play through (but the difficulty is not increased for the invited players).

So while my friends and I had fun playing the game
recommended: there was also a lot of frustration regarding the bugs in the game.  Still I recommend playing it with friends
voteText: and knowing what bugs you will have to guard against.\n\nTL;DR Before playing familiarize yourself with the common bugs here "http://www.warinthenorth.com/forums/forum.php" and make sure to periodically back up your save games."

reviewText:
This is really an excellent game. I have no idea why it scored so low in the reviews.

A good story, excellent voice acting, nice graphics with tons of options for the PC version, and it never crashed on me once. it's a pretty long game (expect about 15-20 hours your first time through on Normal), lots of secrets to find, three different characters to play (each with their own play styles and each of them fun), and it has an absolute metric ton of loot to find, all of which alters the look of your characters, to go along with some good customization options.

The combat is simple but takes awhile to master, and it does get more involved on Heroic and Legendary difficulties, both of which are excellently balanced (though there are a few huge difficulty spikes in certain quests.)

All in all, this is an awesome game, well worth 20 bucks. This is the game Diablo 3 should have been.

reviewText:
TL;DR: A must-buy if you you're running NVIDIA; get ready for giant eagles with majestic pants.

LOTR: War in the North is easily my favorite hack and slash style game. It has a pretty decent storyline, good voice acting, and good graphics, and excellent replay value. You get to talk to some major LOTR characters, and fly around on giant eagles that look like they are wearing amazing feathery pants (I'm not even kidding). The inventory and level-up systems are great, making the RPG element of the game extra fun. The co-op feature is definitely worth getting into as well. I've honestly yet to find a game like this that I've enjoyed nearly as much.

Biggest issue I have with this game is the crashes. In graphics-intensive parts (specifically chapters 2 and 8) it almost never fails that the game will freeze, then crash altogether. This seems to happen with AMD cards and renders the game unfinishable for anyone running on AMD from what I've been able to research. If you're running NVIDIA you should be fine. I actually purchased War in the North used for xbox 360 to avoid a lot of these issues because it was less hassal than swapping out my card.

It's a shame they haven't fixed the crashing problems (it seems the developers have written this one off), or this game would be A+, and well worth the $20. As it stands, however, I'd suggest purchasing the game when it goes on sale, and be prepared to deal with a few bugs. Apart from the bugs War in the North is everything I personally want in a hack and slash RPG; the game itself is fun enough to inspire me to buy it, again, on a separate consol- if that says anything.

reviewText:
It's a decent game, there are just some flaws which bring it down. I originally played through basically the entire game on PS3 until a glitch occurred that made it so I was unable to progress past the spider boss regardless of how many times I beat it.

The game is quite a bit of fun on co-op and the combat is simple and satisfying. However, quite possibly the biggest problem with this is that the game forces voice chat upon you. There is no options in-game to disable the voice, make it push-to-talk, or to even mute other players. There is no way to disable the voice in this game without disabling the audio entirely. This wouldn't be a problem if the game chat was half decent, but from my experience it's delayed, echoey, and just overall unpleasant. Apparently there are work arounds for this, but I couldn't manage to figure them out, and really, I shouldn't have to go through that just to do something that should be so simple. Eventually I found the voice chat as part of the game's charm, but I don't really mean that in a good way.

The skill trees offer a basic variation to each of the characters' playstyles without getting unnecessarily complex. Treasure chests and hidden caches give a reason to off the path in search of better gear. There isn't much exploration to do otherwise, though. If you enjoy always getting new gear and improving stats (like me) then you will enjoy the equipment aspect of this game.

Combat can get a bit tedious and there doesn't seem to really be variation in objectives. It's always going to be go here, defend here, open this all whilst holding off waves of orcs and the like. This is kind of to be expected, though. It's not like there was much else that could have been done with this style of game, but in long sessions you may find the game becoming repetitive.

If you have friends to play this with I would recommend it. Maybe not for $20 though. If you don't have friends, well, the AI isn't all that sturdy from my experience, so you'll be doing a lot of reviving.

Gloin / 10.

reviewText:
6.5/10

War in the North is the tale of a dwarf, elf and ranger wandering the wastes and plains of Middle Earth away from the main events of J.R.R. Tolkien's book and films.

It's a respectful hack and slash action rpg, with the major gripes being the lack of much ability progression and a lot of the same enemies appearing over and over again. A mildly coherent tale against a relatively unknown antagonist is only brought back from boredom due to the rich lore that has been previously established.

Reminded me of the Two Towers on PS2 back in the day. Three characters playing on screen, Each one has their own unique moves, spells, and abilities and you fight against Sauron's minions in the North. One can get involved with alchemy, another with breaking down walls to find treasures, upgradeable weapons, gear armour etc. Other games do everything it offers better. There are a few short appearances from the major LOTR characters in Rivendell but their sudden appearance and disappearance only cements the insignifance of the playable characters. Campaigh is about 10-12 hours long, bit longer I would think on higher difficulties.

Best fun is the 3 player co-op. Got this on a Humble Bundle nearly a year ago, but worth a look if you have it and are itching for an average Action RPG or a LOTR game til Shadow of Mordor arrives.

reviewText:
Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a fun game to play both solo and in (2 or 3-player) co-op.
The story is straightforward but well themed, gameplay is fine and the soundtrack is very nice.

Despite a few issues which I will point out below, the game still gets a thumbs up for me.
The game can freeze or crash on certain systems with AMD video cards and the lastest drivers. On average my game crashed every about every 2 hours. I reinstalled the video drivers and even tried beta versions but this did not resolve the problem. Some say you have to install a really old driver to fix the issue but I have not verified this. Otherwise, the game runs smooth on highest quality, except for the last area which seems to be laggy for a lot of people even with newer GPUs or Nvidia ones.
It feels like the difficulty doesn't scale up in Heroic and Legendary modes. I would not have minded e.g. twice the number of enemies on hardest difficulty.
The game only saves when you see the save icon, so not necessarily after travelling or a boss fight. You might want to talk to a shop keep or smith and cancel out to force a save if you just got some new loot or a reward.
The AI can be derpy at times too. Buddies and enemies can get stuck in some areas or teleport around.
One optional mission (the mithril one) can not be completed without someone playing as dwarf. If you are playing by yourself as either lore-master or ranger you will have to revisit a certain area as a dwarf.
I think there is a money glitch which gives you infinite money once you reach 999,999. At least you can buy some nice equipment for your buddies (like 300k crossbows).
Level capped at 40. It would be sweet to be able to unlock and upgrade all skills and be even more OP. Oh well.
Played on: Windows 7 with Xbox 360 controller, 3 playthroughs as lore-master (1 in co-op), all achievements.

reviewText:
With all the myriad of Lord of the Rings games, we have all have seen the good, the bad, and the inbetween. This one... is AWESOME.There really is not exxagertation in my use of this term. The graphics and voice acting and constant freshness of the storylines inspire awe and leave you feeling the effects of it on a level that is just pure enjoyable FUN.

I have played close to every Middle Earth based game that has existed to date, from pen and paper campaigns to console to old school computer varieties and I can honestly say-I have not played such a purely great Lord of the Rings/Middle Earth game in more than a decade.

A wonderfully fresh and unique storyline within the LoTR Universe,the beautiful graphics, easy controls all add up to make it great.

To to top it all off, it does not even come with any sort of steep or long term learning curve. Less than 30 minutes in, and you will be a pro at controlling every aspect of your character from simple combat to speclized moves.

The voice acting is beautifully done for all cut scenes, both full and user input questioons/responses.

Just a truly wonderful Middle-Earth game, and well worth the investment.

Want more information? You start your role as not one of the major movie characters-but rather, a enitrely new storyline. Connected to the same time as the events of the main LoTR books and characters, but your own adventure. This gives two major advantages: One, the story is fresh and new. You don't automatically know what the next turn in the story will bring. The second bonus is that by having your own character, you have more 'freedom' in the way your character plays out. You have your own opinions and thoughts on the events that happen and are given different options to discuss and respond to them. This makes the character fel like it is yours, rather than you just steering a well-known character down the same, well worn path that everyone knows by heart from the books and films.

The con? If there is a con here-it would be that it may just be too addictive. You can easily lose yourself in it for hours at a stretch.  I honestly have nothing bad I can say about this particular RPG and in such a vast genre with so many options, there are very few games within it that can get this level of praise from me.

Long story short: if you are only going to get one game in a month at this price, any fan of the RPG Genre, and especially lovers of the Middle Earth world, would be well-advised to choose this game to spend their hard earned cash on. It is worth every penny.

reviewText:
LOTR!!!

War in the North!

This is a must have for fans! it's a nice little story coinciding with the main battle in Lord of the rings.

Here you'll meet some of the well known characters of the franchise, which is always a pleasure. (the characters in the movie and in the game have the same faces, so it was nice way to relieve the LOTR movies)

Eagles! Dragons! and verbally mentioned characters which make your nerdy side giggle. (or was it just me?)

The game is fine, the graphics were ok, The hack and slash combat were fine, and everything else.

Though I had an issue with graphics later in the game.(from what I've read, it's because of my radeon GPU)

The game was fairly short, I thought it was gonna be longer seeing so many dots in the map section, but I was wrong.

Grab it on SALE for LESS WALLET GOUGING and MAXIMUM FUN!!! ^_^

equiped character with different items
bosses follow the LOTR

Cons

reviewText: War in the North is an unexpected highlight. If you are a fan of the Lord of the Rings, enjoyed the setting in Skyrim and especially if you are not afraid of some repetitive but challenging Hack'n'Slay action, you might find this game entertaining. I bought it for 5 EUROS and I have to say these are besides of the one I payed for Left4Dead2 the best invested 5 Euros since a long for a game. I enjoy a lot the graphics, especially the great 3d vision support, the music and the unique Lord of the Rings atmosphere. The fighting system starts poor, but gets better while playing and let you really take part in its evolution. Overall, you should give the game a chance as I am sure it will entertain you much longer than some AAA titles for 10 times more of the price. Btw, it has also a great Coop-Modus with some minor glitches. At the moment there are still some players, so you should hurry up, if you want to enjoy this feature. Overall I give it for 8/10 as I am already addicted, even with way too many weird glitches the game sometimes has. But what counts in the end is not if a game is full with different feature, but if it can entertain for quite some time and there War in the North makes far more right than it messe up: 8/10.

reviewText:
This game shines in coop-multiplayer!

I bought 3 copies and played it with my kids, and so far we have not been disappointed. If you are looking for an interesting, simple hack n slash game that works fine with 3 human players, this is it.

Basically an action game, with some simple role-playing thrown in and a linear story to follow, it allows for some really interesting coop playing if you have 3 human players. The whole story depends on your party of threee, so the game already looses much of its charm if only one of the 3 heroes is AI-controlled!!!

I would not recommend it if you want to play alone, there are better single player hack n slash games around. For a good 2 player hack n slash experience I can recommend Hunted" - but if you have 3 players
date: go for "LotR: War in the North"!"

reviewText:
3rd person, hack and slash, story driven, action RPG in Lord of the Rings universe, that follows the story of the Lord of the Rings books / movies, yet is presented from a different angle, where you play as one of the three heroes set on a quest to eliminate Sauron's mysterious ally in the north.

Story is very similar to the movies, and you meet many known characters throughout your journey, like Gandalf, Frodo, Bilbo, Aragorn, Legolas and many more. Most of the time you can only interact with them in safe" hubs like towns and scripted cut-scenes.

Even if you didn't watch the movies

reviewText:
Terrible brawler, everything about the game is wrong down to the most basic mechanics.
Even though the game runs at 60fps with no drops on my system it feels like 25, everything is sluggish and delayed like I'm playing through OnLive. Every movement or action has input delay and recovery animations from being knocked down can take control away from the player for 20+ seconds. Enjoy wailing on an enemy for an entire minute while they make no effort to counter or block you, the enemies in this game are mindless sponges, the only danger comes from being overwhelmed by the endlessly respawning minions as 20 of them crowd you at once.
Invisible barriers and clipping issues are rampant, every object and character has an invisible sphere extending beyond them that will clip with anything you get within about a meter of, making judging distance completely unintuitive. Laugh as all 3 characters get stuck in a doorway that looks like it should easily fit 5.

It isn't hard to make a brawler, and yet this game fails in every category.

reviewText: I got this game in a humble bundle expecting/hoping for something along the lines of Return of the King from the days of old....but nope. Terribly shallow, boring gameplay. Mindless button mashing combat. Forget about combos, just press A for quick attack, or press B for power attack, or Z for weak â™¥â™¥â™¥ ranged attack. Abilities are so dull that you almost never notice that you've used them. Equipment/loot is just like any other ARPG of this type, except with no flavor whatsoever. Story was cliched dribble on top of hilariously cheesy dialog and voice acting. If you want a solid ARPG there are literally hundreds of better choices out there. This game is bottom of the bargain bin at Walmart, but with half decent graphics. It wouldnt meet the expectations of a child raised in the wilderness by wolves who doesnt even know the concept of a video game. Avoid at all costs

reviewText:
Solo[/b] : the AI is dumb as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, the only thing they do good is that they evolve their stuff. I can't finish the game in solo because the AI is too dumb to make the 2 characters use their spells together, the healer never heals, and the dwarf tank never stays attacking the same target, so the ennemies were all at 95% health when the dwarf died :D

Multi[/b] : you can't play with 2 friends, one will always get disconnected. There are some guides to make it work but you have to use some third party software like hamachi or something like that. But it's kinda fun when it works. The race exclusive secrets you can find are cool, sometimes you drop nice stuff, and fights can be epic with bosses when you are using your abilities right.

In conclusion, a good idea on paper, but not enough money to acomplish it :/

reviewText:
I love the game. It's a great hack and slash, with lots of loot.

Pros:
-Great Art work and level design
-Music is Great
-Vocals are great
-Story is great
-Long game of good action and battles
-It's LOTR


Cons:

-Game has a few mechanics with combat that are ok could be better. Just remember ROLLING is your new best friend which will get you out of a lot of annoying situations!
-Game crashes are a major issue with this game. I did manage to figure out what was my problem and fix the crashing. I made a GUIDE on how i FIXED my game which may work for others.
GUIDE:  http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=352462648

-Inventory system is not the best and there is no static placement of items in your inventory
-can't replay zones that you currently cleared to find more loot. (if you are playing the game how it was designed.)
-some creating private game issues. (after a full pc windows reinstall, all of these issues were gone! )

reviewText: I like the LOTR franchise, but the games seem to be hit or miss.  This RPG is the latter.  The game menu is unintuitive and having to exit out of inventory everytime you search an enemy is a chore.  Voice acting is alright, but better for some characters than others.  The story is forgettable and you don't really form any kind of emotional attachment to the characters.  Enemies are what you'd expect, except there are a lot more trolls.  Good lord how I hated the trolls.  Also, there is a boss about halfway through that may have been bugged for me (or not) that took a good 5-10 minute of hacking at his legs to bring down.  I also expected that there would be more areas of the game to explore, as there are more locations on the map than you actually visit.  Apparently they are there to explain lore, but that should have been explicitly stated.  Pass on this title.

reviewText:
Do I recommend playing this game? Yes.
What's the catch? Of course there's a catch:

STORY: The story in this is interesting, but don't expect some major twist. If you played the Third Age, it's kind of that same setup. Your mission is to support the fellowship by distacting Sauron's forces away from Frodo and gang. You'll meet the likes Aragon and Gandalf, but there's one problem: the voice acting. I'll give Gandalf's voice actor credit, he really tries to sound like Sir Ian, but he just falls short. Aragon's is just awful. It's not to the point where I can't listen to it, but don't be suprised when he sound's nothing like his film counterpart.

GAMEPLAY: The gameplay is what I imagine would happen if you took Dragon Age and Skyrim and paid them to make a baby. You've got the run around and find loot off of enemies and hidden chests like Skyrim (Yes, I know Dragon Age has it but I don't have to go find a Rogue whenever I find a chest in this game). The combat itself feels like a mix of Dragon Age, Skyrim, Arkham, and only the slightest hint of Gears of War. You have your two team mates that do somewhat support you unless you're playing in Coop (That's an entirely different discussion) and in a way it reminds me of Dragon Age, except that I have no control over them. It's like Skyrim in that there is no pause feature; you are constantly in the midst of the battle. It's like Arkham in the sense that you have really neat slow motion finishing moves occasionally (Yes, I know Skyrim has those, too, but I think that Arkham's has more in common with the style this game has). When I saw Gears of War, though, I don't refer to the cover shooting mechanic, I mean more of the coop system. Even in a singleplayer game, when you lose all of your health, you will go into a downed position and can slowly crawl to your teammates like in Gears. The constant, Get on that turret!" command also seems reminicient of Gears to me

reviewText:
For the TL;DR people out there - game offers great gameplay, good story, fantastic music and nice visuals.

Aaand now for the other people:

The gameplay is a mix of hack 'n' slash and rpg. It's really fun and doesn't get boring. The game also lets you play as 3 diffirent characters - each of them having diffirent armors, weapons, skills, and their own other characteristic things (Like one being a warrior, one a ranger and one a mage). The only problem with the gameplay that I have is the fact that it's kinda unbalanced. The game itself seems quite easy for the most part, and the challange missions are overly hard. Though it still isn't a huge problem in my opinion, thankfully.

The story is a not-too-complicated, good and entertaining story. SMALL SPOILER Though you get to meet the characters from the original LotR story, which is quite rad

The soundtrack is really good and has that LotR-ish style, of course. It really fits your current environment in the game.

The graphics are quite good (except on the main menu, where for some reason they are awfully blurry, but that's just the menu) and puts attention to small details - like your character getting temporarily dirty after rolling on the ground. The game also makes some really badass looking view changes and slow-motion when delivering the final blow to the last enemy in your area, which is awesome.

Really reccomending buying this game to people who like actiony games.

reviewText: This game is a lot more fun than initially expected, the mechanics work well and the levelling process is interesting enough to max. The story is compelling though not as much as the serie it is derived from. It plays easier and is more compelling when played with two friends. The side stories are nice and give for a fine additional touch. However the game does not arrive without it's flaws because If played alone (speaking from own experience) it might get repetitve. Creating the combination strategies with up to two friends and trying to complete the hardest modes is what makes the game fun. With a possibly ignorant AI the latter is difficult to achieve. Therefore I recommend the game, however do not buy it just because you are a fan of the series because you might get dissapointed without your favourite heroes being playable and but little references made to them throughout the story. Besides all this I hope you have fun playing it if you decide to buy it.

reviewText:
Attention fellow gamers!

After just 17 hours me and my friend finished a single playthrough of the game in co-op. We discovered something: this game is a must in co-op! We had loads of fun and we were frustrated more than once when we couldnâ€™t kill a boss or troll. But in the end we got through and concluded that this game is more than awesome!! On the other hand we were let down by the final battle, which was simply tooooooo easy, since we had more difficulty defeating the first boss in the game.

THE STORY: We were pleasantly surprised by the fact that the story is interwoven with the actual storyline of LOTR. You even come across characters as Aragorn, Gandalf, Lord Elrond, Legolas and Gloin (known from the Hobbit-trilogy) and even Frodo and Bilbo Baggins. You follow three companions (Eradan, Andriel and Farin) on their quest to defeat a minion of the dark lord Sauron. On their way they make several friends and stops in the north of Middle Earth.

GRAPHICS: Not bad at all for a game that is already 4 years old. We saw a fair amount of detail on armours, buildings and the like and didnâ€™t realise we were playing such an old game.

INTERFACE: Convenient use of hotkeys and a useful minimap! The inventory was a little off, since you had very limited
space and images for additional and trivial objects in the world of Middle Earth.

GAMEPLAY: We found it very useful that you could see the name of your friends on screen even if they were in an entirely different place/room. A very useful feature of the game is that you have the option to exchange items with other players that are only suitable for that particular race. Conveniently enough there several sell/buy/return to civilisation-points.

-	For the Ranger: Very smooth movement of the character during a fight and one of the current reviewers enjoyed the swordplay a little too much at times. We liked the convenient switch between two-handed, one-handed, dual wielding and bow very useful. And, contrary to some other RPGâ€™s,  the realism of being attacked whilst you are looting or switching weapons was very satisfactory to us! We loved the critical, brutal, legendary, etc. strikes with the swords and headshots with the bow too. They lead to some pretty funny ways of dying! We wouldâ€™ve loved an alternative attack with hotkey â€˜2â€™ while using a two-handed sort, but that could just be because we didnâ€™t unlock every skill in the skill tree.

-	For the Lore-master: Andriel has some great abilities to use in combat, as a supportive mage. For example, she can conjure a magical shield that can protect you against arrows and magical blasts. She also can use her staff as a melee weapon, that is actually quite strong. Because of her Elven ancestry, Andriel can use herbs to fabricate potions to support herself or her companions. This can be decisive at some points in the game.

-	For the Champion: Not applicable (yet), but Farin is awesome!! He got us out of trouble more than onceâ€¦more like a thousand timesâ€¦LOL.

Overall conclusion: â€˜Lord of the rings: War in the northâ€™ is a must if you are a fan over LOTR, RPG and/or co-op gaming. We had hours and hours of fun (and yet more to come on Heroic and Legendary difficulty) and we didnâ€™t get bored with the storyline once. And once again: THIS GAME IS AWESOME!! *No addiction what so ever* Hahahahaha!!

Enjoy the game!

reviewText: LOTR: War in the North is.....difficult...to recommend. It's a really fun to play action rpg, especially in co-op, and has some good (albeit visually dated) designwork. The combat is gritty and satisfying. Story and characters are decent, but not particularly memorable. The adventure is fairly epic, and sends you to some interesting places in middle-earth.\n\nAnd now that we've covered the positives, on to the regretable bit: It seems proper quality assurance wasn't implemented or Warner Bros just said the product was good enough." I've played this game on the Xbox 360 and the PC
date: and BOTH versions have severe game crashing bugs. It is so bad
recommended: that I cannot progress any further in either version
hoursPlayed: though I did get much further on the PC. WB was apparently working on a patch years back
voteText: but that seems to have gone nowhere.\n\nI had bought the 360 version used
helpfulPercent: and the PC version through a humble bundle event. If I had bought it at normal retail price
votesHelpful: I'd have demanded my money back. It's a shame really
votesTotal:
since the game is pretty fun otherwise. I can only hope WB realizes the full value of good quality control and testing. I get the feeling they just cut the QA department's budget (or the dept. completely) to save on development costs.
A real damn shame...

PS: So far I've only heard of issues plaguing gamers with AMD GPUs. Nvidia owners might not experience these bugs."

Its a lot of something, but nothing..
Its just a mediocre liniear hack'n'slash game, that has been disguised with some RPG elements (level system, skill tree, armor, coins)..And when you are engaged in conversations, it does not matter which of the answer you choose, they all lead to the same return answer..


If you dont mind a mindless linear hack'n'slash.. and you like the whole LOTR universe then this game might be for you.. But i wouldnt recommand picking this up for above 5 euro's..

Personally, i lost interest in it quite rapidly.. Maybe its better if you play it in coop, might save this game a bit.

reviewText:
LOTR: WITN is an adventure/hack'n slash/RPG game aimed to be played in CO-OP. If you can't recruit 2 more friends to play along, brace yourself, 'cause you gonna suffer. As I said, aimed to co-op, means the whole history is played with 3 characters at the same time, of which you just can control one. The other two, if you don't have anyone to share the struggle with you, will be given to the most annoying/dumb/â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ IA ever made. This is kinda annoying but if you have friends to play with you, the experience is very rewarding and funny.
From my PoV, I find odd how this game was abandoned by the developer. It will not require THAT much of effort to tune this game and adjust some minur stuff.
Needless to say, the lore is very interesting and the overall 'RPG experience' is nice (concerning loot and build-craft). I would like more choices to make and not only the illusion of choice.

ps: About bugs, I just finished the game with friends, but one of them was not able to save the game and unlock the Heroic Mode. So we went back there to help him. But AgandÃ¢ur just bugged big time, and my char is stucked in the last piece of land in Carn Dum, without hope to be released.

reviewText: Jeez, I don't even know where to start. To make things simple, if you can buy this on sale for $5 or less, then I'd say it's probably worth playing if you're into generic hack and slash RPGs. Otherwise, this could have been an awesome reimagining of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance or Champions of Norrath but falls flat in so many areas.\n\nCombat encounters are loads of fun at first because you're not hindered by the awful AI partners; they can actually kill enemies, revive you, and face groups on their own without your constant babysitting. About 6 hours in (of around 12-14), the beefier enemy types stop reacting to your moves which turns the fun hack and slash combat into a chore of XXY
voteText:
and reviving your AI partners because they don't block or roll. About another 2 hours after that, though, you run into enemies who interrupt your attacks and can stun lock you, so good luck reviving anyone once one of your partners is down unless you're lucky (or play Ranger and abuse his Evasion skill).

There's also no sense of empowerment as you gain new abilities and equipment. Even ignoring the fact that most abilities (for even the Lore-Master/Wizard) are just boring power attacks that have a cooldown, they never end up doing enough damage to make them feel worth while as you progress through the game. New enemies are thrown at you in such a way that by the time you're doing significantly more damage, the enemies have double the health they used to.

I'm not sure how common the technical issues are (seems like more of an AMD thing), but unless you want to downgrade drivers you can probably expect to deal with an inconsistent framerate that BOMBS for seemingly no reason at certain points in the game. Bugs are littered throughout as well, but I didn't run into anything that wasn't solved by quitting and reloading a checkpoint.

I should note I didn't play any coop in the game, so maybe that saves some of the issues with its combat, but it's hard to believe the studio that made the amazing Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath released this. It could have been so much more.

reviewText:
Great game. Tells the adventures of three characters who are supposed to defeat the evil sorcerer Agandaur. He is a servant of Sauron himself.
During the game we control one hero, but at any time we can go out to the menu and change to another . We can also play with your friends in co-op. We choose a knight, a magical elf or dwarf. Every characters have a very extensive skill tree.

Except to the main thread there is a mass of non core tasks for which we get the experience and valuable items.
When searching very interesting locations we will face many opponents from the orcs to the huge snow trolls.

Graphics are very nice and pleasing to the eye.

I recommend.

reviewText: War in the North delivers a well-paced narrative which was born in the non-canon events of Tolkien's Middle-earth. While Frodo and the Fellowship were dangling from a pitchfork above a kettle, the northern lands were defended by stalwarts (unknown) heroes, of which you happen to be part of. As you progress through the story you'll come to realize that, no matter the difficulty, your NPCs are dull and won't serve you well in dire situations.\n\nThat's where CO-OP mode kicks in. Secure a Teamspeak server with your friends, form your heroic trio and go kill some of Sauron's lackeys. FOR GONDOR!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A beautiful game that deserve to be played.

Although the price may seem to be sligthly too high, it is definitelly a must once one sale. You'll get 10-14 hours of story about the Middle Earth and will follow a group of 3 heroes that try to make difference at the North. A story trully is beautiful and you'll meet some characters from the book/movies, will get to talk to them as well, which in my opinion was a great plus to the story.

As I already said before, the story itself is beautiful. Characters are well writen, music is beautiful, voiceacting is perfect and atmosphere is fantastic. Another thing that I found to be great (although didn't used it myself too much) was the ability to switch between characters in the end of each level, so that you could try all playbable character without starting the game all over again. Co-op is also an option (although I played solo because I wanted to get into the story as much as possible) and it is infact a lot of fun !

All in all, I really did enjoyed the game and can't but recommend it!

reviewText: Jeez, I don't even know where to start. To make things simple, if you can buy this on sale for $5 or less, then I'd say it's probably worth playing if you're into generic hack and slash RPGs. Otherwise, this could have been an awesome reimagining of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance or Champions of Norrath but falls flat in so many areas.\n\nCombat encounters are loads of fun at first because you're not hindered by the awful AI partners; they can actually kill enemies, revive you, and face groups on their own without your constant babysitting. About 6 hours in (of around 12-14), the beefier enemy types stop reacting to your moves which turns the fun hack and slash combat into a chore of XXY
voteText:
and reviving your AI partners because they don't block or roll. About another 2 hours after that, though, you run into enemies who interrupt your attacks and can stun lock you, so good luck reviving anyone once one of your partners is down unless you're lucky (or play Ranger and abuse his Evasion skill).

There's also no sense of empowerment as you gain new abilities and equipment. Even ignoring the fact that most abilities (for even the Lore-Master/Wizard) are just boring power attacks that have a cooldown, they never end up doing enough damage to make them feel worth while as you progress through the game. New enemies are thrown at you in such a way that by the time you're doing significantly more damage, the enemies have double the health they used to.

I'm not sure how common the technical issues are (seems like more of an AMD thing), but unless you want to downgrade drivers you can probably expect to deal with an inconsistent framerate that BOMBS for seemingly no reason at certain points in the game. Bugs are littered throughout as well, but I didn't run into anything that wasn't solved by quitting and reloading a checkpoint.

I should note I didn't play any coop in the game, so maybe that saves some of the issues with its combat, but it's hard to believe the studio that made the amazing Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath released this. It could have been so much more.

reviewText:
TLDR: Third Person hack/slash RPG similar to Dragon Age 2, but set in Tolkienâ€™s Middle-Earth. Melee combat has a similar feel as the first Witcher game where you kind of need to flow from one hit to the next to build up strike power. The game appears to be built around multiplayer co-op, but Iâ€™ve only played single-player thus far. WARNING: If you have an ATI/AMD video card you will probably have technical trouble with this game. Big thumbs down for the game breaking bug (near the very end) - 2/10. Would have been 6/10 if the game actually worked.

If you liked Dragon Age 2 more than you liked Dragon Age Origins (not many people do) you might want to give Lord of the Rings: War in the North a try. The game is more linear and focused on combat than world-building. This might have to do with the fact that the â€œmain storyâ€ is happening elsewhere (Fellowship of the Ring) and youâ€™re just the distraction to help Frodo sneak into Mordor.

You play one member of a trio of adventurers at around the start of the first Lord of the Rings novel. Before Frodo, Aragorn, and their buddies start their journey to Mount Doom, Farin the dwarf (melee fighter), Eradan the ranger (archer), and Andriel the elf (mage) are fighting the good fight against the servants of the dark lord Sauron, who are led by a bad dude named Agandaur. Since Agandaur is Sauronâ€™s right hand man fighting the bad fight in the north, your goal is to smash him and draw Sauronâ€™s attention away from the south, where the Fellowship of the Ring are making their way into enemy territory.

The game is played in the third person perspective and while you can only play as one of the three characters at a time, you get opportunities to switch which character youâ€™re playing between game chapters. Really though, you should probably stick with one character per playthrough because the game will auto assign the stats and skills of the characters you arenâ€™t using when they level up, and you wonâ€™t get much opportunity to customize if you keep switching around. Unlike the Dragon Age games, you donâ€™t control the whole team, just the guy youâ€™re playing. Also, youâ€™re controlling all your characterâ€™s attacks as well, not just designating a target.

Like many hack and slash action RPGâ€™s you run into a lot of loot and equipment in the game. You pretty much have as many equipment slots as Diablo 2, but most of the gear you find is â€œnon-magicalâ€ and can be easily compared to similar pieces. This means there isnâ€™t much in the way of randomly generated loot stats, and you donâ€™t need to spend much time grinding for items. In fact, you probably shouldnâ€™t even buy weapons from the vendors because chances are youâ€™ll just find something better in about 10 minutes.

Pros:
+Co-op gameplay available so you can go through the single player campaign with a friend or two. Each character has a unique â€œsecret findingâ€ skill that can only be used when a human is controlling the character (in single player, you only find secrets that your character can â€œseeâ€) so if you have a full team of human players you can find all the secrets in a level. Also, bear in mind that like many squad based games, you can revive your allies if theyâ€™re knocked out. So you donâ€™t need to spend too many healing potions if you know your buddy can just bring you back to life at full health.
+Decent story that takes you all over Middle Earth (well, a lot of it) and involves some of the characters from the Lord of the Rings books/movies. Why donâ€™t the eagles just fly everyone everywhere? Play the game and find out!

Cons:
-This is the big one. If you have an AMD video card like I do (Radeon 7850) you will find the game has extremely poor frame rate at many places. I was unable to finish because at the last chapter, the game slowed to a crawl and would crash out repeatedly at the same place. Searching online, this seems to be a problem for a lot of people. My friend has an nVidia GPU and didnâ€™t have this issue.
-The â€œcritical hitâ€ system of the game can be fun sometimes but after a while it gets really repetitive. You built up power by continuously hitting a single enemy uninterrupted and eventually you can use a power attack with a chance of instantly killing them. Problem is, this means it takes like 2 minutes to kill many of the more powerful enemies, especially near the end of the game. Also, you only hit one enemy at a time no matter how wide your swings look, so attacking large groups of bad guys is really annoying (the little ankle-biters keep interrupting your combos against the big guys).
-Despite how linear the game plays, itâ€™s still possible to miss side quests because many of the quest items are randomly dropped. Cleared the whole area and didnâ€™t find the special quest rock? Too bad for you, play through it again.
-You canâ€™t see the enemyâ€™s life (except for bosses) and most bad guys seem to have a ton of life. This is probably intentional to force players to use the critical hit system more, but it means every fight seems artificially prolonged. Should it really take 50 hits to kill an orc?

Overall, the game is fun (when itâ€™s working) if you enjoy hack and slash and want to dive once again into Lord of the Rings lore, but thereâ€™s a lot of room for improvement. The fact that there are 3 playable character classes is reason for replay, but from what Iâ€™m told theyâ€™re mostly the same. If this game is in your backlog you should push it back in favor of something better, but itâ€™s worth playing eventually: IF you have an nVidia graphics card. The gameâ€™s developers have abandoned the project so the crashing/low frame rate issues will not be fixed. The 90% of the game that I got to experience was sort of fun.

reviewText:
If you have an AMD card, don't bother, you're just going to have a mess of problems in Chapter 2 and Chapter 8. I managed to get through Chapter 2, despite the crazy amount of frame drops, stuttering, crash to desktops, had to restart the computer a few times, etc. Chapter 8 though. I just can't do it. I manage to get to a part where I'm supposed to find a lever after travelling through a series of sewage pipes under a fortress and the game just freezes up after a crazy amount of stuttering and frame drops. Just not good optimization for AMD cards.

The game itself isn't bad. It's a fun action RPG in the Tolkein universe, so I was sold right away. You get to choose one of three characters, a man, a dwarf, and an elf. And you're not stuck with just that character, you can switch off in the main menu and continue from where you left off with any of the other characters. The combat is neat, but maybe a bit repetivie. The graphics are okay, but the character animation is pretty terrible. The combat animation, however, is actually great. The story isn't too compelling but you get to explore recognizable parts in the Tolkein universe as well as areas that have been mentioned but not necessarily explored in the novels or films. Basically, the plot involves the three characters banding together to fight off an evil force to the north while the Fellowship travels south towards Mordor.

I should mention the gameplay as well. It's extremely linear. Basically, you enter an area which is counted as a Chapter"
date: and you continue along a path in that area in Middle-earth until the end of the Chapter. So it's not open world if that's what any of you wanted to know.\n\nIf you have an Nvidia card and are a Tolkein fan
recommended:
this game is good fun for its duration. No real replay value though.

7.0/10 (Nvidia cards)

5.0/10 (AMD cards)"

reviewText:
***** ATI USERS BEWARE, AS OTHERS ALREADY MENTIONED, THIS GAME ISN'T OPTIMIZED FOR YOUR CARDS AND IT WILL RANDOMLY CRASH. NEAR THE END OF THE GAME IT WILL CONSTANTLY CRASH. *****

^ I didn't know that before i start this game, so it dissapointed me.

The game itself is a casual RPG game, a nice way to spend an evening or two. Nothing special.
It's somewhat repetitive with the battles but nothing tragic. It's fun and simple.

Not recommended for ATI users as well. Near the end it was literally unplayable because it was crashing constantly at Carn DÃ»m, stuttering and it was full of artifacts. I tried many guides with the hope it can be fixed, but nothing helped significantly. And some guides suggested to update bios or install older drivers. Of course i wouldn't go so far and put my self into such trouble for this game. I managed to complete it, by giving my save files to a friend of mine with nvidia so he could pass the point where my game was unplayable.

Anyway, despite the terrible optimization, the game is okay, has okay graphics, it's a bit slow with the dialogs. Wouldn't spend money on it though, maybe when it is -85% off. If you have money and nvidia, take it.

reviewText:
If your are playing this as a single player it might work, however if you are interested in playing this with a friend or two, abandon â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Theres plenty of working co-op games out there and this is not one of them.

Here is some of the problems you will face if you try to play this game in co-op:

The game features its own voice chat function which works so poorly that you will not be able to understand a single word because of the bad sound quality. THERE IS ALSO NO WAY TO DISABLE IT. I had to download a virtual adio cable program just so I could actually chat with a friend using another program while playing.

If you were lucky enough to get into another players game, buckle up for strange crashes, disconnects when visiting windows and a good spike in your blood pressure every time you try to give an item to your friend. It will most likely vanish into thin air.

Getting used to the menus will take longer than I ever put into this game since they are made for a controller. There is mouse support but much of it is just nonsense.

I will have to say that the game supports alt + f4 so escaping its horrors is quick and easy.

reviewText:
While this game eyes great, it does have a lot of potential. However, various things deny that potential. 5 second knockdowns, your companions blocking your way, no flinching upon being hit resulting in just dropping dead, litte logic within the story line and to much a linear way to play.

Also, having to choose a single class and the game forcing you to play that class till the end of the game, since all the fancy equipment you gave to your AI companions will be gone when you select them. Making sure that once you change, you've got no way to match the equipment to that level, unless you buy yourself the equipment, which is only possible after  you've reached Rivendell.

All in all, if the devs payed some more time upon developing the game, it would've been recommendable and enjoyable. Now it's just a frustrating experience I must add. So, if you're looking for a decent Lord of the Rings slasher, I'd suggest playing the games made 10 years ago, or the somewhat newer Middle Earth: Shadows of Mordor.

reviewText:
Don't buy this. This game was hastily ported over to PC and has too many problems to list. Me and my friend purchased it on sale to just play through togeather, not excpeting much other than a cheap game to waste a weekend or two. First thing you'll notice is the terrible in-game mic and the fact that you can't turn it off at all, which means if you have TS or Skype going you have to decide between terrible quality or an echo.

Secondly the game crashes and glitches out constantly. Some are just funny things with NPC interations or ragdolls but other would break the game by not allowing you to progress any further because a boss or event decides not to show up. Our golden example of this was when the Final Boss decided he didn't want to show up for the fight, effectivley breaking our save file at the end of the game. Even reloading doesn't fix it. It's also terribly optimized in certain parts of the game. I have a decent computer that can run most new games at the highest setting yet there would be fits of lag in crowed areas, the worst being Chapter  8 where you crawl though the rust tunnels. I had to look at the ground the entire time else I would instantly crash.

Mediocre game full with breaking bugs. Don't bother.

reviewText:
What can I say.... this game is just mediocre. No seriously, like after the whole OMG its Aragon! OMG I can cut orks heads off and OMG most of the fellowship in rivendale, it just dies down to repetitive game and a character progression reminescent of skill trees of the old but half the size, yea no wonder it is just eh.

Im not saying this game is bad and all but it is just not fun! I admit as a fan of the fantasy genre, I love Lord of the Rings, but this game is said to be a side, non-canon story, but it is still a good story none the less, and that is what pushed me to finish the game.

It is a standard hack and slash affair, but in this case, the controls feel sluggish and sometimes irresponsive, and I can see this is just a console port to PC. Also it doesnt help that every mob apart from 2 out of the 6 archetypes there are, will knock you down and make you immobile for a good 5 secs, which you wait for your character to stumble around and get up. Like the only 3 moves those 2 do will constantly knock you down and they are the most common of enemies in this game!

This game is definately not worth the amount it is asking for now, it is rentable at best from a video store for $1 or $2, whatever it is at your store, and the only reason why I got it on PC is cos it was in the Humble Bundle and I got it without a choice and I wanted FEAR.

Also did I mention that your team mates are solid and if you played single player like I did, they would stand there and be in your way and not move until after 3 seconds of running into them. Yea..... 2/5!

P.S. Coop is dead on PC!

reviewText:
Pros:
Good story
Fun Combat
Decent aesthetic appeal

Cons:
Broken multiplayer
Mediocre leveling system
Very Linear

Why I cannot recommend this game:
My friend and I purchased this game to play together, it was a fun experience for about 30 minutes before he was booted from the game for seemingly no reason. He was able to rejoin soon after, but about ten minutes later it happened again. This time the game said he was unable to play with me any longer as I had progressed in the multiplayer too far, though I had only remained in the game an additional 2-3 minutes. He caught himself up to where I was on his own, but the game still did not allow us to play together anyway.

reviewText:
Moderately fun, and with ok graphics and gameplay, this game lacks in story for even a hardcore LotR fan such as myself. There's frankly not enough in this game for me to recommend it to any but other LotR fans.

Multiplayer changes this up a bit, though. The game doesn't get any harder with multiple players (unlike other games), so it only becomes easier, but it's fun to party with friends and see who can kill the most orcs and goblins.

RECOMMEND?: Only to hardcore LotR fans.

reviewText:
This game is bad.

Don't get me wrong, it's actually really fun to play. However, the game is clunky, looks terrible, voice acting is bad, and the story is so boring and forgettable that I don't even remember what my characters name is, so I just call him Gimli. Otherwise... well you might be a bit upset.

reviewText:
**TL;DR This game is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ version of Dragon Age: Origins, which came out a year earlier. If you want this kind of experience, then go play that as a dual wielder. War In The North is a brand-riding money grab that's repetitve, boring, and has LoTR as it's one and only thing that anyone could possibly like this game. Srsly go read the wiki for the story, this game is not worth it.***

The one thing this game has going for it is the fact that it takes place in the LoTR universe. The aesthetics and the graphcs are mediocre, the voice acting is actually pretty good, but the game play is pretty bad.

The controls are unresponsive and wonky, the level design is not obvious, the enemies are repetitive and boring... I got to the part after the stream of sappers and was just too bored to continue. Oh look, I axed another one. Oh wait, I'm the archer because I'm an idiot and they make you buy arrows instead of giving them to you. Let's be the mage..... aaaaand she's a healer.

What the means is that this game is CLEARLY MEANT TO BE PLAYED AS THE DWARF. If I have to spend my money on arrows (because you do not find enough to not buy them), then my equipment is going to be lacking. I'll let the AI control that. If you're going to play a healer for NPCs then you're either too lazy to play and just want the story or you're too lazy to read the summary on Wiki. Either way, letting the computer shoot unlimited arrows and toss heals at you is really the only way it makes sense to play this game. I know this because the dwarf wa the last class I played and it was the only way I could even tolerate this game. I fought the troll as the Ranger... which basically meant I watched my teammates do Up-Downs like it's pre-season football.

Which really lends insight into this game. Why even have those other classes if they're so much less effective than the dwarf? Really, the entire game just seems like a brand-riding money grab to me. Even the death animations on the enemies are repetitive... The game really holds no new interesting thingsdo I fly in the face of Mostly Positive reviews? I don't really know, to be honest. This game is really just a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ Dragon's Age: Origins, which came out a YEAR EARLIER.

reviewText:
You can consider yourself lucky if your game hasn't crashed while in-game without a recent save.

The game(play) itself is good, the combat is enjoyable and satisfying. But with the bugs and crashes, this game is a dislike from me.
The crashes happen at random times, and it's annoying if you haven't recently saved the game, as you'll have to repeat again to the spot where you was when it crashed. When you go down, both AI try and help you, therefor drawing the attention of enemies to the reviver, and getting knocked down while being revived. Terrible AI, they cannot navigate very well.

I'm on a low-end video card (Radeon R7 240 2GB) and I can run this on Max settings, including Motion Blur, etc at 1600x1200 with decent fps. The mouse movement is terrible, it's jaggy and I can't spin/turn fast without getting confused.

It can get repetitive, but at times you forget it's getting repetitive and continue.

Gameplay 7.2/10

Stability (Bugs & Crashes) 3/10

AI 4/10

reviewText:
Definitely worth a try.
I think the expectations have doomed War in the North. Since it's Lord of the Rings title, players and Middle-Earth fans alike anticipated something grand, a game that will finally maximize the potential of LotR in a video game. It didn't happen to the extent everyone expected. Yet it doesn't mean War in the North is an inferior product. Far from it.
You play as one of three available characters - a Ranger, Dwarven fighter and Elven mage. Each have three main skills at their disposal and a handful of minor ones. Even though the trio is a bit bland, they are likeable. The story runs simultanously to the Frodo's quest, which is a nice touch - your actions feel relevant as your party contribute to the greater cause.
The gameplay features a lot of hacking, slashing, shooting and looting. You face the horde of goblins, orcs and trolls under the command of one evil Agandaur, who is neatly tailored as a villan. War in the North offers an abundance of loot - here I would like to mention that the equipment in this game is superbly designed. The details on weapons and armor are fantastic, the overall feel of the equipment you find or buy fits the world perfectly, which is a nod to the coherent Tolkien universe and at the same time a welcome break from all the overdone, tasteless and improper design in most of the modern RPGs (a sexy female warrior with armor covering only her breast and groin area? Yes, practical indeed). On your travels you will visit locations and meet characters well-known from the books and movies (Ian McKellen voices Gandalf).
The game's length is reasonable, around 10 hours for a playthrough, and the replay value is here. War in the North is best enjoyed while playing with your frineds in a co-op mode. It's essantially the same campaign as the single player, but obviously more challanging as the opponents grow in strength with each additional player.
Recommended. I approached War in the North without any expectations and was pleasantly surprised by the overall quality - it's not one of the best games you will ever play, but it's certainly enjoyable.

reviewText: The fighting is great. The story is impressive(I have never read the original). You don't need to collect equipments like Diablo. Although some character skills will break the balance of the game which influences your game experience(For your game experience, you should never or less use those skills), I still want to play second or third times after I complete a playthrough. reviewText:
Experience has usually left me very cautious whenever I see a licensed videogame, particularly when itâ€™s tied in to a film franchise. It seems that virtually every blockbuster in the past 20 years has had an awful accompanying game aimed at cashing in on the hype surrounding the name. Iâ€™ve usually felt differently about the Lord of the Rings games because theyâ€™ve been pretty good (the tie-ins on the original Xbox were actually pretty great) so I approached this one with rather less cynicism than Iâ€™d usually reserve.

Itâ€™s immediately obvious that this isnâ€™t a high quality, high budget title. The cast impersonators are the first clue and every member of the original cast that appears in the game has an actor that sounds not-quite like what weâ€™re used to hearing. The crude visuals, basic soundtrack and the sense that theyâ€™ve hired one voice actor to cover every other NPC were a little disappointing, though not enough to be off-putting.

So, yet another 3rd person hack â€˜nâ€™ slash, this one with the most basic of plots; â€œthat guy is Sauronâ€™s mate, letâ€™s kill himâ€. Obviously, being a mate of Sauron heâ€™s quite powerful and has many orcs between him and your party, so youâ€™ve got to kill them off first. The plot is as simple as that. On the way you encounter some of the characters shown in the films, as well as some only mentioned in the books, (minor spoilers, though itâ€™s not like the story here is that important!)  such as Gwaihir, Elladan and Elrohir, Radagast the Brown and Halbarad the Ranger.

Levels are very simple, with three or four stages to each level and a peaceful base every few levels where you can return to repair, buy and sell items and turn in quests at occasional checkpoints. You wonâ€™t spend very long there though; the main part of the game is either chopping up orcs or running towards the next lot of orcs to chop up.

Gameplay is very repetitive and, though the combat is very functional, it gets quite dull as you go from one stage to the next doing the same bloody thing over and over. Combat is quite a standard affair, with standard fast and heavy attacks melee attacks, a ranged attack and the options to block and dodge. The controls are functional and work well enough, but everything feels quite floaty and a little detached. Each character has unique abilities that can be unlocked and upgraded as the character levels up, most of which are pretty cool to execute. The problem is in how repetitive it becomes as you take on endless hordes of a very unvaried enemy. I often compare these types of games to God of War, but thereâ€™s a reason for that; in those games, there are dozens of various attack types and thereâ€™s a huge variety of enemy types, all of which require different tactics to combat. In this case, War in The North has 4 basic enemy types â€“ a melee guy, a ranged guy, a sorcerer and a troll. Sure, there are technically more, with goblins, Uruk Hai and so on, but all they really are is the same thing with better stats â€“ which doesnâ€™t mean anything as they are only encountered later in the game when your own stats have also grown massively. This effectively means that youâ€™re fighting the same group of things in a sequence of different rooms for the entire campaign, broken up by the occasional mediocre boss battle and combat is broken down to a sequence of dodge, attack, dodge, special attack for the entire campaign. Not exactly Ride to Hell, but hardly a prize winning game either.

Visually the game plays it safe, using the same design aesthetic as in the films, although without any of the grand scenery or set pieces that I loved about the trilogy. The settings are familiar and just a little bland, but it does the job. Itâ€™s in the graphics that the game shows its limitations, especially in the resolution and framerate. This game looks like a last-gen console port and even running at 1080p it doesnâ€™t look like itâ€™s in HD. Framerate is similar, even though FRAPS showed it running at a solid 60fps it certainly didnâ€™t look like anything approaching that, in fact it felt like 20. I donâ€™t know why everything looked so poor, or why the framerate randomly dropped to 2fps for a few seconds at random, or why the last level is so glitched you have to reinstall 2 year old drivers for your GPU to run the sodding thing, but itâ€™s very poor form and quite infuriating. That these issues havenâ€™t been patched, despite the forums being flooded with various technical issues, is pretty disgraceful.

War in the North is one of those licensed games that get a recommendation because itâ€™s â€œgood enoughâ€. If, like me, youâ€™re a fan of The Lord of the Rings, youâ€™ll probably enjoy going toe-to-toe with a horde of orcs and just being in Middle Earth. The game almost loses my recommendation due to the technical issues and game breaking bugs and if you donâ€™t want to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ about fixing it yourself then Iâ€™d advise you to steer well clear. If youâ€™re fine with that, itâ€™s a pretty decent distraction for a few hours.

My score:

6/10

Itâ€™s a good enough game; quite repetitive, and pretty average combat, but itâ€™s a good amount of fun carving through a mass of orcs.
