reviewText:
Lord of The Rings War in the North is surprisingly a very competent game. It cannot compete with the AAA titles with hand to hand combat and fantasy element, but it is good enough to be worth at least one play through. From the start it is evident that the developers put great effort into the game to make the environment shine with detail and realism. I was surprised to see such quality of level detail, despite the levels and gameplay being linear.

The character models and armor are very detailed as well. Every time you put newer more advanced pieces of armor it reflects on the model of your chosen character. Be it helmets, arm guards, leggings, body armor. All of it. It is also very accurate as far as movie content. Human, Elven, and Dwarven armor and items are what you'd have seen in the Lord of The Rings movies. It is not surprising since the publisher of the game is WB.

Positives written above do not come without the negatives. Nearly every level, no matter how spectacular in appearance, has plenty of invisible walls. These invisible barriers can be incredibly frustrating because often you'd find yoruself checking whether you can go in a particular path only to find that it is simply blocked by an invisible wall. As is the case with even the best games on the market, the level design becomes less impressive, and often shows plain lazyness as the player reaches the 2nd half of the game, and eventually the ending. Some areas start looking less detailed and more rushed. Invisible walls become bigger, lighting less consistent, etc.

War in The North also has issues with inventory organization. You may eventually gather enough weapons or armor to fill all the alloted slots in the inventory. Some items can be old, other items too high for current level, and there is no way to organize them. Neither manually nor automatically. You cannot select an item and move it in the inventory. Player just ha sto move the cursor over the items to see the stats of each.

Another rather inconvenient drawback is in the design of the game for those who want to play single player as opposed to 3 player coop. You have the option to give" your excess items or items meant for other two classes to your CPU controlled teammates. This is a very poor design gaffe because CPU does not  always equip the item gifted to them
date: nor compensate the party for the item value. Once it is given to a teammate controlled by the CPU the item is as good as gone.\nThis is not an issue if you play coop with 2 or three players. The other player actually gets the item and can use it. Similarly
recommended: when you play coop you can actually exchange items with each other to acquire complete sets of items meant to be worn together. They may be strangely acquired by your CPU partners

voteText: but you are not able to either put it in any "shared chest" nor give to another player. Wasted opportunity.\n\nCombat is very satisfying and as the character levels up you have a wide choice of upgrades and moves and magic spells to pick from. The upgrade tree is very similar to that of Borderlands games in which you have three columns of skills which you invest points in to unlock the most powerful ones on the bottom. Once again

reviewText: There are times you want to play dungeon crawlers and you look to the online where you will rack and stack yourself at end game with specific builds, items, and do your research and reading.  There are other times you want the simple joy of killing a lot of creatures in a nicely themed area, with a mild bit of challenge, gear and leveling that is easily managed, and played with a friend or two.  This is a wonderful dungeon crawler to unwind to, and the kills are quite visceral (that awesome level of physics and gore that'd you'd expect when a goblin meets an axe wielded by a dwarf in combat).

reviewText:
I started playing this game with very low expectations. It didnâ€™t seem all that impressive from the trailers so I just said to myself: â€œYet another one of EAâ€™s attempts to milk the Lord of the Rings cash cow.â€
A couple of hours of hacking orcs with a friend changed my view of the game drastically.

The first and most important thing you should know about the game is this: Do NOT expect a fun solo experience. This game is meant to be played with a friend or if at all possible, two.
It is at its best when you are communicating with your friends in order to take down tough enemy groups and help each other survive difficult encounters.

A lot of people are complaining about the simplicity of its design, but honestly, thatâ€™s what makes it work so well. The combat is straightforward and impactful (I suggest a gamepad but mouse and keyboard controls work well also) and the looting is surprisingly fun.

War in the North wonâ€™t make you care too much about its story though. It isnâ€™t very memorable or interesting in any way for that matter. This could have been improved upon by having the player actually make meaningful decisions. Unfortunately, the dialogue options seem to be there just to give you a little more information if you really want it.


From a graphical point of view, the game is quite ok. You wonâ€™t be amazed by it, but occasionally, you might find yourself nodding to a slow motion decapitation or some other small detail (like how the snow sticks you your armor after you roll through it).
This is indeed the grittiest Lord of the Rings game released and it feels great. If you wanted a more mature and accurate video game based on Tolkienâ€™s books, this might be your thing.

The sound is so and so. The music is great as always but the voice acting really put me to sleep. The greatest thing about it is the built in voice chant. It actually takes into account things like the distance between characters and the environment. For example, if a friend is in a cave and talks to me, his voice will have an echo. (I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever encountered a game with a similar feature)

Is it a good game? Hell yeah! If you are a fan of co-op games, it will be hard to be disappointed with War in the North.

I'd say an 8 out of 10 would be the grade. Not that it matters.

reviewText: This was a very enjoyable game to play with my friend, until the last level, at which point the walls flashed colors and I got disconnected and had to progress in single player, still fighting bugs and glitches. I beat the boss with him, and we started the next difficulty. A side quest glitched and we couldn't complete it, but mainly it went the same as before, with me struggling to checkpoint my way through to the final boss. On the third an final difficulty, however, I got more bugs than ever before, all ending in a whopping save glitch that returned me to halfway through the first playthrough. My friend is on the doorstep of the final boss on the highest difficulty, and while I should be there with him, I'm all the way back, more than half his level, unable to join him unless I wade through a see of bugs again. This game is so full of unfixed bugs it's ridiculous. It's a fun game, but not fun enough to play through again without my friend.\n\n2/10, would not buy again.

reviewText: Gameplay itself is actually quite fun in co-op and the story is interesting (if not a little cliched), especially if you're a Tolkien fan. That said, there's several annoying bugs to be wary of. The game forces you to use Steam Voice in co-op, which is counter-intuitive in the likely scenario that you're already using a better form of voice communication. The game crashes frequently in graphically intensive situations, and this is a commonly reported issue for AMD card owners with post-HD5k era GPUs. The aggregate score of 66 seems fitting, as those looking for this type of game should enjoy it if they're willing to tolerate its issues. Get it when it's on sale.

reviewText:
I started playing this game with very low expectations. It didnâ€™t seem all that impressive from the trailers so I just said to myself: â€œYet another one of EAâ€™s attempts to milk the Lord of the Rings cash cow.â€
A couple of hours of hacking orcs with a friend changed my view of the game drastically.

The first and most important thing you should know about the game is this: Do NOT expect a fun solo experience. This game is meant to be played with a friend or if at all possible, two.
It is at its best when you are communicating with your friends in order to take down tough enemy groups and help each other survive difficult encounters.

A lot of people are complaining about the simplicity of its design, but honestly, thatâ€™s what makes it work so well. The combat is straightforward and impactful (I suggest a gamepad but mouse and keyboard controls work well also) and the looting is surprisingly fun.

War in the North wonâ€™t make you care too much about its story though. It isnâ€™t very memorable or interesting in any way for that matter. This could have been improved upon by having the player actually make meaningful decisions. Unfortunately, the dialogue options seem to be there just to give you a little more information if you really want it.


From a graphical point of view, the game is quite ok. You wonâ€™t be amazed by it, but occasionally, you might find yourself nodding to a slow motion decapitation or some other small detail (like how the snow sticks you your armor after you roll through it).
This is indeed the grittiest Lord of the Rings game released and it feels great. If you wanted a more mature and accurate video game based on Tolkienâ€™s books, this might be your thing.

The sound is so and so. The music is great as always but the voice acting really put me to sleep. The greatest thing about it is the built in voice chant. It actually takes into account things like the distance between characters and the environment. For example, if a friend is in a cave and talks to me, his voice will have an echo. (I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever encountered a game with a similar feature)

Is it a good game? Hell yeah! If you are a fan of co-op games, it will be hard to be disappointed with War in the North.

I'd say an 8 out of 10 would be the grade. Not that it matters.

reviewText:
Honestly... The game could of been harder, people are saying it needs co-op... Honestly... That's what this game lacks. This was a big let down for me as I have played other LOTR games that were much better than this... It seems they whipped up the story line as fast as they could, the acting was horribly done and the story was far too breif. The action combat style of the game was the only thing good about it. However, the AI was dumber than previous LOTR games. I would of loved to give this game a great review, but it didn't quite reach my expectations as a LOTR game.

Sure you take a good amount of damage if you're hit, which is why people probably find this game moderatly hard, but honestly, that's all it was. They hit you hard, and harder on higher difficulties. The AI did not get smarter, just simply, your health pool took more damage. So if you know how to strike and move, this game is beyond easy...

So mainly what I'm disliking the game for is...

1. Dumb AI
2. Very breif storyline
3. Extremely easy
4. (Just throwing this out there) I expected more mobs. There wasn't that many to fight, and they came in small waves that were easily controlled.

What's good about the game?

1. Combat Style

reviewText:
The game is good. Really good, and takes all the majestic setting of the Lord of the Rings book. Yes, book, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ the films. So, why not recommend it?

SOLO gameplay is boring, and the game can shine only in co-op.
CO-OP gameplay, though, has a really broken talk feature that you simply can't shut off. Were it good enough to understand your partners it would be a great thing to have, but it lags over a 10-years old codec and you can't really get anything out of it that isn't annoying. And they're not fixing it.

I can't recommend this game on Steam, unless you are firm to play co-op without microphones. For everyone else, crack it and play on tunngle using skype or teamspeak to speak with your friends.

reviewText: This game has quite a few primordial building blocks of a great game, but it loses it on the details. First, the game looks fairly decent. Graphics could be tuned up a bit (mainly with some textures), but overall, they aren't bad. Gameplay is a mixed bag. The characters move well enough, but there are some annoying collisions that will hang up your heroes, including places that heroes" should be able to travel through (like stepping up a set of stone stairs from the side instead of moving around to the first step and stepping up that way - or trying to step down off a rock ledge a mere two feet off the ground below). Music is reminiscent of the movie and the sounds and mannerisms of the creatures in the game ring true. The game would be a fun 3-person co-op game

reviewText:
Performance of the game:
This game is a buggy mess.  I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.

Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all â€œ0â€s and an x or 5 thrown in.

I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.




The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)
one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.


Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.

I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.

Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G maâ€™s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.



Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

reviewText:
If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.

Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this game

Is the story any good?
Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.

Is the combat any good?
Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.

Is there customization?
The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.

Diversity?
Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.

All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?
There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.

What is wrong with it?
The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.

My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP.

THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.

All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.

reviewText:
I wanted so bad to like this. The story is interesting and the combat isn't bad. It was fun while it lasted, however multiplayer with friends is far more fun than single-player. Best I can say is...if it's on a sale, go ahead and get it. It's fun while it lasts.

Now...here's where things get messed up with multiplayer. The multiplayer is broken and absolute trash. It'll work when you're connected and work fine. My first major complaint...the voice-chat is on...permanantly. If you have a built-in mic for your laptop, everyone will hear everything. You cannot turn it off. Just have to turn the mics off and/or disconnect them. It's a severe pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ and the developers don't give a crap. There is no save state for multiplayer for those who join your game. That's right...nothing.

During a game of 4 hours, someone disconnected and rejoined...however. They were reset and lost all of their gear. It was just gone. The multiplayer state was just in a broken status. I really wanted to love this game, it drew me in a lot...but...just had issue after issue that I could not tolerate.

reviewText:
Lord of the Rings: War in the North is a hack-and-slash game. That's... it.

You control one of three characters with no personality or character development trying to chain as many finishers as possible, until you unlock Farin's Explosive Arrow and trivialize the game. Even the only vaguely challenging sections, which are the optional horde challenge maps. Along the way you will meet other fan-favorite characters such as the Fellowship, but then you will discover they have about as much relevance to you as this game does to Tolkein's legendarium. Sorry, Lord of the Rings fans.

Your mission is to go kill the leader of Sauron's forces in the North, Agandaur. He is pathetically easy, but it's worth it (?) to see the CGI animation that probably ate up 70% of the budget for this game.

The only way this game becomes decent is if you somehow game one, preferably two, friends into playing it with you. The time commitment shouldn't be that bad because the game is both easy and short. Playing with friends helps disguise some of the game's more egregious single-player faults, such as an incredibly limited inventory system, no ability to switch between characters on the fly (this requires you to completely reload the game), and the fact that some parts of the game are straight-up inaccessible without two or more players.

Fortunately the game isn't super glitchy (there are some glitches but reloading usually fixes it) or unplayable, and you'll probably unlock 95% of the achievements without even trying.

Sadly, War in the North failed to live up to any of its promise. It's not a HORRIBLE game by any means, but there are way better uses of your time.

reviewText:
Everything about this game screams mediocre.  I'll break each aspect of the game down below:

Graphics - stuttering and muddy.  Everything is in dark earth tones for the most party and tends to becomes a black/brown blur.

Sound/music - For the most part this is the best part of the game, or at least the part that sucks the least

UI/Mechanics - The UI is horrible.  There's just no way to say it more clearly.  It is easily one of the worst parts of this game.  The levelling and talent trees are lackluster, the HUD during gameplay is incomprehensible, and the combat is sloppy.

Story - Yes, it's set in Middle-Earth, and they have gotten a lot of the names of people/places directly from the lore, but that doesn't make the story actually interesting.  Essentially, you are a small band of adventurers (a man, an elf and a dwarf, super original) that need to distract Sauron's forces from the ringbearer during the time of the LOTR trilogy.  Really, it's just a hack and slash-fest that is completely uninspired and boring.

reviewText:
The co-op element of this game cannot be emphasized enough:  this is inherently a co-op game.  I played single-player and so my comments are reflective of that experience.

The game includes three characters:  a dwarven tank, and human ranger who can choose between melee and ranged DPS, and a support/ranged DPS mage.  The three characters have decidedly different roles in combat and the fundamentals of the combat system are good, but other design flaws quickly mask those positives.

Gameplay is episodic, with small, linear maps broken up with portals back to town.  Each character has a small number of actions, making combat somewhat repetitive.  Town is a dull place with a few vendors, the interface for which is clumsy and inefficient.  Managing and building your character and gear is more tedious than rewarding.

The main flaw in the game is that you are tighlty tied to a single character.  Rather than giving the player the power to smoothly transfer control between characters on-the-fly (which I would think would be a very easy, obvious feature they should have included), you must play as a specific character for the entirety of a level while the other two are controlled by AI.  You cannot even equip gear on a character other than the one you are currently controlling.

I admit I did not spend a lot of time in this game, maybe it would have gotten better as the game progressed, but to be fair I quit playing the game because I did not enjoy it.

An average co-op experience that is haunted by technical problems, the major one being an always activated steam voice chat when playing with other people. Unless you have no other co-op game at hand, I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game is a very generic-feeling beat 'em up. I played through the game with a friend quite some time ago and we found ourselves trudging through the game for completion's sake more than anything. We stopped after one play through, unable to muster the gumption needed to play through the campaign a second time on new game +.

The few characters you have to choose from are all rather boring archetypes. You gain new class abilities over time that let you perform special moves, but nothing here seems particularly inspired.

There was also pretty severe bug on a couple of the levels that was causing the to become exceptionally bright, almost to the point of the screen being a blinding white color. And sometimes it would rapidly blink in and out of this mode. I'm not sure if it was some intense bloom effect bug, or what it was, but it nearly made those levels unplayable.

The game was bland and over all boring. It was certainly not for me, so I cannot recommend it to others, however if beat 'em ups are your thing then perhaps you will still find something here worthwhile.

reviewText:
If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.

Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this game

Is the story any good?
Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.

Is the combat any good?
Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.

Is there customization?
The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.

Diversity?
Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.

All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?
There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.

What is wrong with it?
The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.

My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP.

THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.

All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.

reviewText: This game was very appealing at first, although it is rather disapointing. Let's start with the good things. It has amazing graphics and kill 'mini cutscenes', and does have rather good combat. But, the voice acting is horrible! If you have scene the LOTR movies, the voice acting for Elrond is laughable. They even had the audacity to put really bad american voice actors in the game. LOTR is mainly british (based on the movies and the books) and yet they chose average sounding american voice actors for some roles. Also, the story is very bad, and isn't original at all, because you are directly connected to the fellowship. At least have a seperate storyline, but no, they have to come up with a completely unoriginal, boring storyline. Also, there is abosultely no character development, and I think that if it wasn't for the good gameplay, I would have quit this game. Don't waste your money buying this game. It ISN'T WORTH IT!

reviewText: When I recieved this game I was hecka excited. I had finished this game on my friend's Xbox 360 only months before and enjoyed playing it with him in Co-op mode. After finshing this game on my PC I realised how boring and repetitive the game really was. The game is not a free-roaming or exploring type. It restricts you to the very bone with it's story levels, which are the only things that you can actually do in this game. Sure, myself being a huge Tolkien fan should enjoy this game a lot, but the lore is barely touched on. There are refrencing to the movies and books but no huge give away of what the game/story is actually about to all new-comers. If your looking for a Middle-Earth game with heaps of lore and factual basings on Tolkien's work, please, please buy Shadow of Mordor. I did so on my Xbox One, and have to say, it's probably one of my favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
I wanted so bad to like this. The story is interesting and the combat isn't bad. It was fun while it lasted, however multiplayer with friends is far more fun than single-player. Best I can say is...if it's on a sale, go ahead and get it. It's fun while it lasts.

Now...here's where things get messed up with multiplayer. The multiplayer is broken and absolute trash. It'll work when you're connected and work fine. My first major complaint...the voice-chat is on...permanantly. If you have a built-in mic for your laptop, everyone will hear everything. You cannot turn it off. Just have to turn the mics off and/or disconnect them. It's a severe pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ and the developers don't give a crap. There is no save state for multiplayer for those who join your game. That's right...nothing.

During a game of 4 hours, someone disconnected and rejoined...however. They were reset and lost all of their gear. It was just gone. The multiplayer state was just in a broken status. I really wanted to love this game, it drew me in a lot...but...just had issue after issue that I could not tolerate.

reviewText: It's LOTR which is a good point but after about seven hours it becomes clear that it hasn't been thought out and simply piggy-backs off the main films rather than creating a new element. The RPG aspects feel added in to make the game more meatier but instead highlights how bland it is with stiff dialogue that offers little change to your play-through.  The ranger has the ability to go undetected but there is no stealth in the game, there is no difference in any of the three classes, all three offering almost identical game-play. Your teammates cannot be commanded and often just run in and  not get killed but instead crawl around following you as you attempt to revive them, only to have twenty orcs leap on you the second you do killing you in a few hits. I could go on and mention many more annoying things but as a whole the game experience is boring and frustrating, shame as there are moments when you think it may not be that bad, oh wait, Yes it is!

reviewText:
Honestly... The game could of been harder, people are saying it needs co-op... Honestly... That's what this game lacks. This was a big let down for me as I have played other LOTR games that were much better than this... It seems they whipped up the story line as fast as they could, the acting was horribly done and the story was far too breif. The action combat style of the game was the only thing good about it. However, the AI was dumber than previous LOTR games. I would of loved to give this game a great review, but it didn't quite reach my expectations as a LOTR game.

Sure you take a good amount of damage if you're hit, which is why people probably find this game moderatly hard, but honestly, that's all it was. They hit you hard, and harder on higher difficulties. The AI did not get smarter, just simply, your health pool took more damage. So if you know how to strike and move, this game is beyond easy...

So mainly what I'm disliking the game for is...

1. Dumb AI
2. Very breif storyline
3. Extremely easy
4. (Just throwing this out there) I expected more mobs. There wasn't that many to fight, and they came in small waves that were easily controlled.

What's good about the game?

1. Combat Style

reviewText:
Performance of the game:
This game is a buggy mess.  I powered through a very bad bug in chapter 2 of the game that would have it randomly crash, took about 3 hours to pass a single section that should of took about 20 minutes, twice crashing seconds before triggering the saving in the game.

Most of the times it crashes it doesn't crash to desktop it blue screens my computer most of the time not giving a reason just something failed and the memory address of all â€œ0â€s and an x or 5 thrown in.

I have made it through chapter 7 with it crashing about every half hour and now in chapter 8 of the game I found another section that will crash every few minutes similar to chapter 2 of the game.  Now I have to quit.




The actual review of the game (based on when it is not crashing)
one of the first things you get is a bird friend and you hit the 4 button to call for his aid.  Well the Elf character has a power that has you block and hit 4 (holding CTRL then hit 4).  even though the 4 icon has changed from the bird logo to a different logo, BOTH powers are used; the bird and area heal.  I wasted a lot of bird power trying to keep the other 2 friends alive.


Defense missions are the worst part, it goes fine until the enemy brings in the giant troll and he walk past you not caring that you are attacking him and then kills the thing you are protecting in 15 seconds.

I personally am more of a dodger power and like to dodge and not much blocking, I would of liked a double dodge (I only played the elf so I do not know if the other characters have a double dodge).  After facing a double sword enemy who is stabbing you so much that you can not dodge, I have learned to block against them just be for they attack and then attack them back.

Dialog was interesting even had a few points that you could try to tell some one that we are just passing through this very remote area to get to grandma's house (not exactly G maâ€™s house, but you are lieing about what you are doing so I thought it appropriate) and the NPC has non of that, but a very interesting choice to tell them.  Also there is a lot of repeat dialog choices that are represented as new choices.  Example: someone tells you of a castle; new option of the castle in dialog choices, npc just repeats the thing that brought up the new choice.



Combat was fun and interesting, slowly adding in new enemies over the 6 chapter's I played.  I would of loved to see how the ending turned out and if they kept adding new enemies through the end, but sadly the bugs and crashing my computer is enough to make me stop.

reviewText:
Players looking for a fun role-playing game should definitely consider this.

The combat is very hack-and-slashy, but I often find myself utilizing features such as blocks and interrupts which I hardly ever touch in other games. Large enemies such as trolls require me to use the combat roll to get out of the way, and I actually have to ration my health potions. The game does have some combat abilities (such as power hits that are on a cooldown), but I personally don't use them very much.

The companion AI is very well done. I've noticed one companion position herself so that her spells benefit both me and the other AI, instead of just spamming her abilities off in a corner somewhere.

The armor system in the game is relatively interesting. I find myself actually comparing stats on armor and looking for gems to boost my armor's base stats. I also have to be careful with my funds so I can afford good armor upgrades when I find them on shopkeepers.

The game IS linear. At times, I have felt an almost on-rails feeling, but other times it's surprisingly open. The game has a lot of hidden chests and caches that encourage exploring every corner of the map. The items from these caches are typically very useful.

The game has many side-quests that are typically optional. You may revisit quest hubs in the world to complete these side quests at your leisure.

I'm not a fan of the Lord of the Rings, but even I got into the story. The dialogue has a very nice RPG feel to it, and the voice acting is incredible.

reviewText: If you get past the fact that the coding for this game is utter â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, multiplayer is unstable (as well as the rest of the game) and the horrible attempt at a built in mic chat (that you can't turn off) it's pretty damn good. The textures in this game are really spectacular, the detail to everything from dust on your clothes, notched weapons, echo in the game chat while you're in a cave. The combat is simple but every kill feels rewarding. As you run through orcs and goblins drenched in their blood you can't help but to feel some adrenaline. The story, being set in Middle Earth, is just what you'd expect from the universe of Tolkien. The established locations like Bree and Imladris are nice to look at but the never before seen areas add to immense size of Middle Earth. If you get this game expect to be frustrated by the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥-poor coding but know that you won't easily get bored.

reviewText:
A seperate story that is connected to the events that take place in the Lord of the rings trilogy.

You are able to play three different characters. A human ranger, a dwarf champion and a elven wizard. Archetypes from the realm of middle earth and as a party you and your companions embark on a quest to aid the fight against evil in the form of an avatar of Sauron.

This is a very engaging story and gameplay that requires commitment to roleplay, your character and your companions. You will be able to play for yourself or with 1 or 2 friends, when finding your way through hordes of goblins, orcs and trolls.

Three words would describe why this game is great. Story, atmosphere and gameplay.

The only thing that really concerns me is the inability to disable ingame voice chat. There is a workaround for it, but it should be implemented as an on/off option in game settings.

PRLU SCORE: 7/10

reviewText:
If you read the top reviews for this game, you'll notice the good review, but there is a GOOD reason for the low metascore. The amazing reviews ons team are most likely because the only people who will buy this game are already avid LOTR fans. I however, was not a fan beforehand and will deliver a serious review.

Here's a complied list, and at the end of the list I'll let you be the judge of whether or not you wish to dive into this game

Is the story any good?
Absolutely, as any RPG you have the freedom to partake in the story or to skip it and get into the action. Talking to the villagers of every town will get you side quests in which you can earn some intense gear.

Is the combat any good?
Personally, the combat is pretty repetetive, but it does allow for some customizing, much like dragon age.

Is there customization?
The customization is limited but it IS there, which is better than no customization. Note: You may only customize AFTER starting the game.

Diversity?
Yes, you're able to pick one of the three heros and go along with it, there's also multiplayer functions so you can bring two friends and each have their own hero.

All of these things are good, so why is this a downvote?
There is only one bad quality, but you must realize the depth of the how terrible it is to understand why it's a thumbs down.

What is wrong with it?
The game crashes OFTEN. This game was released on Nov. 1, 2011 which wasn't too long ago. Yet, the game runs like it was made in 2002, with how the graphics are I originally thought this game was made in 2006.

My computer is really new, and it is capable of running Bioshock infinite on max settings, yet it cannot run LOTR War in the North for over an hour without crashing. What's more, is that it does not simply crash the game/window/application. It crashes the ENTIRE DESKTOP.

THIS IS WHY THE GAME RECIEVED A LOW METASCORE, IT IS INCREDIBLY UNSTABLE. It is borderline unplayable, because up until the undead level, you don't really have any problems with crashing. but the second you get to the undead mobs, the game cannot control it's own software and seeminglye xplodes upon itself. And, because the undead levels are canon, you MUST pass through them. I was lucky because my computer was new, so I had a long grace period before it killed itself, but any run of the mill computer may not be able to handle it at all.

All in all, this was a great game, if it wasn't so cancerous to it's own programming, I as a person who is not a die-hard fan of LOTR can honestly say this would have recieved an 85-95 score for what it brings to the table. However, an amazing game CANNOT HAVE A FOUNDATION MADE SUITABLE ONLY FOR GAMES 5 YEARS BEHIND ITS TIME.
